to share you can do so with #thoudostjest on any social platform © caryn shepler a k a beadedgeek 2025 1 thou dost jest history jesters were an integral part of renaissance society whether a jester at court or a traveling jongler these individuals were exempted from societal caste systems and identified as such by their costumes called motley the motley rule was the more ridiculous the better bells extraordinary hats like the cap n bells masks brightly contrasting colors and patterns on their clothes giant ruffs ruffled collars and a variety of peripheral items to draw attention when they entered a room were commonplace for the jester more serious iconography was often usurped for their means including the monks hood and the royal scepter nothing was off-limits the motley allowed them to speak freely regarding political and social issues they could speak about the concerns of their time in a way that was perceived as non-threatening or comical they could deliver bad news with a joke softening the blow they could poke fun at prominent members of society without fear of reprisal they were able to gather and pass information unnoticed they were able to move between societal groups unhampered this was the jester s privilege more than simple entertainers they were responsible for transferring cultural information like songs gauging the temperature of the populace and sparking social change the jester is just as much a part of our society today known by many names their legacy grew into a variety of fields including circus acrobatics clowning and performance groups like cirque du soleil even late night stand-ups and batman have to give a nod to the joker their influence on our culture can be seen just as easily now as when they wore their motley in the renaissance each jester had his or her own definitive look depending on where they were or who they were performing for some clowns even have their face designs patented making each one individual and unique now you can build your very own jester with this pattern required materials ● yarn in 2 or more colors ● crochet hook ● fiberfill ● yarn needle ● embroidery floss for eyes and/or safety eyes optional materials* ● sewing head pins ● embroidery needle ● charm s /bells ● jump rings ● chains ● pliers/jump ring tool ● beads buttons pom-poms tassels feathers other embellishments as desired ©
